segment.source: Creating a New Device Function Driver
segment.target: Creating a New Device Function Driver

segment.source: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new device function driver.
segment.target: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new device function driver.

segment.source: Device function drivers are different from filter drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.
segment.target: Device function drivers are different from filter drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.

segment.source: To learn about device function drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see What is a Driver?, Choosing a Driver Model, and Device Nodes and Device Stacks.
segment.target: To learn about device function drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see What is a Driver?, Choosing a Driver Model, and Device Nodes and Device Stacks.

segment.source: To begin, first determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in Device and Driver Technologies.
segment.target: To begin, first determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in Device and Driver Technologies.

segment.source: To learn about which driver models are available for your device, see the documentation for that particular technology.
segment.target: To learn about which driver models are available for your device, see the documentation for that particular technology.

segment.source: The recommended driver model varies from one technology to the next.
segment.target: The recommended driver model varies from one technology to the next.

segment.source: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF) or the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF).
segment.target: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF) or the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF).

segment.source: For other technologies, the documentation explains how to create a minidriver that is part of a driver pair.
segment.target: For other technologies, the documentation explains how to create a minidriver that is part of a driver pair.

segment.source: Minidrivers go by a variety of names, including miniport and miniclass.
segment.target: Minidrivers go by a variety of names, including miniport and miniclass.

segment.source: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:
segment.target: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:

segment.source: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.
segment.target: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF.

segment.source: In the middle pane, select User Mode Driver (UMDF).
segment.target: In the middle pane, select User Mode Driver (UMDF).

segment.source: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.
segment.target: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.

segment.source: For more details, see Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template.
segment.target: For more details, see Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template.

segment.source: Note When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
segment.target: Note When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

segment.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
segment.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

segment.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.
segment.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.

segment.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
segment.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

segment.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the interfaces that you need to implement.
segment.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the interfaces that you need to implement.

segment.source: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.
segment.target: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select WDF.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select WDF.

segment.source: In the middle pane, select Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF).
segment.target: In the middle pane, select Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF).

segment.source: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.
segment.target: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.

segment.source: For more details, see Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template.
segment.target: For more details, see Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template.

segment.source: Note When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
segment.target: Note When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

segment.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
segment.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

segment.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.
segment.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.

segment.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
segment.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

segment.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the methods that you need to implement.
segment.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the methods that you need to implement.

segment.source: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a minidriver model.
segment.target: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a minidriver model.

segment.source: If your device technology has a miniport, miniclass, or some other kind of minidriver model, check to see if Visual Studio has a specific template for the model.
segment.target: If your device technology has a miniport, miniclass, or some other kind of minidriver model, check to see if Visual Studio has a specific template for the model.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver.

segment.source: Browse the list of installed templates to find a template for the type of minidriver you need to write.
segment.target: Browse the list of installed templates to find a template for the type of minidriver you need to write.

segment.source: If there is no template for your type of minidriver under Windows Driver, click Online and browse the templates that are available online.
segment.target: If there is no template for your type of minidriver under Windows Driver, click Online and browse the templates that are available online.

segment.source: If you find a template for your type of minidriver, select the template, fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.
segment.target: If you find a template for your type of minidriver, select the template, fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.

segment.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your minidriver.
segment.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your minidriver.

segment.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
segment.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

segment.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.
segment.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.

segment.source: If your device technology has a minidriver model, and you are not able to find a specific template for your type of minidriver, the Windows Driver Model (WDM) template is most likely going to be your starting point.
segment.target: If your device technology has a minidriver model, and you are not able to find a specific template for your type of minidriver, the Windows Driver Model (WDM) template is most likely going to be your starting point.

segment.source: Refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance.
segment.target: Refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance.

segment.source: In rare cases, you can use KMDF to write a minidriver, but usually the starting point is WDM.
segment.target: In rare cases, you can use KMDF to write a minidriver, but usually the starting point is WDM.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, choose New | Project.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under Windows Driver, select WDM.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under Windows Driver, select WDM.

segment.source: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.
segment.target: Fill in the Name and Location boxes, and click OK.

segment.source: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.
segment.target: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose Add | New Item.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose Add | New Item.

segment.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, select C++ File (.cpp), enter a name for your file, and click OK.
segment.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, select C++ File (.cpp), enter a name for your file, and click OK.

segment.source: Note If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the .c extension.
segment.target: Note If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the .c extension.

segment.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.
segment.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.

segment.source: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.
segment.target: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.
